entry.title: Tunisia arrests suspected militants after museum attack
entry.summary: Islamic State militants have claimed responsibility for the attack, but social media accounts tied to an Al Qaeda-affiliated group in Tunisia have also published details purportedly about the operation.

entry.title: Tunisia arrests suspected militants after museum attack
Tunisia says museum gunmen trained in Libya
entry.summary:
In a speech marking the anniversary of independence from France in 1956, he stressed that Tunisia's "first challenge is security" and urged "national unity".

Essebsi also met French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve, who expressed solidarity with Tunisia, visited wounded French tourists and placed a wreath at the Bardo.

Tunisia has taken pride in forming a democratic government and achieving stability since the Arab Spring -- in marked contrast to countries such as Egypt and Libya.

entry.title: Tunisia museum terrorists were trained in Libya
entry.summary:
Several well-armed groups in Libya, which borders Tunisia, have pledged their allegiance to the Islamic State.

Police in Tunisia have arrested five people described as directly tied to the two gunmen as well as four others in central Tunisia said to be supporters of their cell.

entry.title: Tunisian official: 2 gunmen trained in Libya before attack
entry.summary: Rafik Chelli, the Interior Ministry's top security official, said the attackers had slipped out of Tunisia in December and received weapons training in Libya before returning home.

entry.title: Plans for leisurely visit in Tunisia turn to horror
entry.summary:
Rubio, who is pregnant, was uninjured and told Tunisia's health minister at a hospital maternity ward that tests showed that the baby girl on the way was OK.

He noted that extremists had generally attacked security forces in Tunisia's rural west near Algeria in recent years.

entry.title: Plans for leisurely visit in Tunisia turn to horror
Obama pledges security cooperation after Tunisia attack
entry.summary: Obama also commended Tunisians for their response and called Tunisia's democracy a "powerful example" for the region.

entry.title: Militants, ISIS Included, Claim Tunisia Museum Attack
entry.summary: The authorities there arrested at least nine people suspected of being accomplices as major cruise lines indefinitely suspended stops in Tunisia, a sign of the looming toll on the crucial tourist industry.

entry.title: Islamic State claims responsibility for Tunisia museum attack
entry.summary: Until now, Tunisia's most deadly group was the Oqba Ibn Nafaa brigade, which is allied to al-Qaida and based in the mountains near the Algerian border.

entry.title: Islamic State says it killed tourists in Tunisia
entry.summary:
It offered Tunisia counter terrorism help.

Italy's Costa Cruises, a unit of Carnival Corp CCL.N, canceled stops in Tunisia.

entry.title: Islamic State group claims deadly attack on Tunis museum
entry.summary: Tunisia has seen an upsurge in Islamist extremism since the 2011 revolution that ousted longtime strongman Zine El Abidine Ben Ali and sparked the Arab Spring uprisings around the region.

entry.title: Poland Sends Doctors to Help Poles Hurt in Tunisia
entry.summary: Around 300 Poles were vacationing in Tunisia at the time of the attack, according to tourist offices.

entry.title: 17 foreign tourists killed in Tunisia were cruise passengers
entry.summary:
On Thursday morning, both the MSC Splendida and Costa's Fascinosa ship left Tunisia with their remaining passengers, bound for Barcelona and Palma de Mallorca, respectively.

Separately, Italy announced it was beefing up its military presence in the Mediterranean to better protect against extremist threats from Libya and Tunisia.

entry.title: 17 Foreign Tourists Killed in Tunisia Were Cruise Passengers
entry.summary: MSC chairman Pierfrancesco Vago said the company hoped to return to Tunisia, but that for now tourists view it as a "no-go zone."

entry.title: Islamic State claims responsibility for Tunisia attack
entry.summary: In claiming responsibility for the attack, the Islamic State group issued a statement and audio on jihadi websites applauding the dead gunmen as "knights" for their "blessed invasion of one of the dens of infidels and vice in Muslim Tunisia."

entry.title: Islamic State group claims Tunisia attack that killed 23
entry.summary:
The Islamic State group issued a statement Thursday claiming responsibility for the deadly attack on Tunisia's national museum that killed 23 people, mostly tourists.

Spanish tourist Cristina Rubio, who is four months pregnant, rests at the maternity ward of the Charles Nicolle hospital in Tunis, Tunisia, Thursday March 19, 2015.

People hold a Tunisian national flag as they demonstrate in front of the National Bardo Museum a day after gunmen attacked the museum and killed scores of people in Tunis, Tunisia, Thursday, March 19, 2015.

entry.title: Islamic State claims deadly Tunisia museum attack
entry.summary:
Interior ministry official Rafik Chelli said the two men had been recruited at mosques in Tunisia and travelled to Libya in September.

The assault -- the most deadly attack involving foreigners in Tunisia since a 2002 suicide bombing in Djerba -- came at a fragile moment for a country just emerging to full democracy after its pioneering popular uprising four years ago.

Islamic State, which has declared a caliphate in large parts of Iraq and Syria and is active in Tunisia's chaotic neighbour Libya, praised the two attackers in an audio recording as "knights of the Islamic State" armed with machineguns and bombs.

"We tell the apostates who sit on the chest of Muslim Tunisia: Wait for the glad tidings of what will harm you, o impure ones, for what you have seen today is the first drop of the rain," the Islamic State audio said in Arabic.

Four years after a popular revolt toppled autocrat Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisia has completed its transition to democracy with free elections, a new constitution and compromise politics between secular and Islamist parties.

entry.title: Islamic State find allies among Tunisia militants
entry.summary: The largest group was known as Ansar al-Shariah movement and in a bold showing of strength in 2012, some 4,000 group members of the movement gathered in Kairouan, Tunisia, one of Islam's most revered cities.

entry.title: Tunisia Hospitable to Islamic State Recruiting
entry.summary:
In the wake of the revolution, men with beards were suddenly everywhere in Tunisia as the fall of the secular dictator emboldened extremely pious Muslims known as Salafis to begin preaching across the country.

In Tunisia, Ansar al-Shariah has since gone underground and its diffuse networks of support are believed to be behind isolated attacks over the years, including failed suicide bombings in October 2013 at Tunisian tourist sites.

In 2013, a band of fighters called the Oqba Ibn Nafaa brigade, named after the 7th-century Arab conqueror of Tunisia, pledged allegiance to al-Qaida's North African branch.

entry.title: ISIS claims Tunisia attack that killed 23
entry.summary: The statement described Wednesday's attack in Tunisia as a "blessed invasion of one of the dens of infidels and vice in Muslim Tunisia", and appeared on a forum that carries messages from the group.

entry.title: Islamic State group claims responsibility for Tunisia museum attack
Tunisia: Death Toll Reaches 23
entry.summary:
The attack Wednesday on Tunisia's National Bardo Museum left 23 dead, scores wounded and threatens both Tunisia's fledgling democracy and its struggling tourism industry.

Tunisian Prime Minister Habib Essid, in an interview with France's RTL radio, said Tunisia was working with other countries to learn more about the attackers, identified as Yassine Laabidi and Hatem Khachnaoui.

entry.title: Tunisia gunmen known to authorities; 2 Spaniards hid all night in fear
entry.summary: The attack spells oceans of trouble for the tourism industry, which brings throngs of foreigners every year to Tunisia's Mediterranean beaches, desert oases and ancient Roman ruins - and which had just started to recover after years of slump.

entry.title: Islamic State group claims Tunisia attack that killed 23
entry.summary:
A unidentified relative of a victim of the attack, center, is escorted at the morgue of the Charles Nicolle hospital in Tunis Tunisia, Thursday, March 19, 2015.

Foreign tourists scrambled in panic Wednesday after militants stormed a museum in Tunisia's capital and killed scores of people, "shooting at anything that moved," a witness said.

entry.title: Death toll in Tunisia museum attack rises to 23
entry.summary: Four others said to be supporters of the cell also were arrested in central Tunisia, not far from where a group claiming allegiance to al-Qaida's North African branch has been active.

entry.title: Britons 'Caught Up' In Tunisia Museum Terror
entry.summary: David Cameron said on Twitter he was "appalled" by the attack, adding: "My thoughts are with those affected. UK stands ready to support Tunisia."

entry.title: Tunisia museum shooting: British woman killed in terror attack named as Sally Adey
entry.summary: US first lady Michelle Obama, on a visit to Tokyo, also paid tribute to the victims, saying: "I want to express our condolences over the horrific events yesterday in Tunisia. Our hearts go out to the loved ones of those killed they are very much in our thoughts and prayers today."

entry.title: Gunmen kill 19 in attack at museum in capital of Tunisia, birthplace of Arab Spring
entry.summary: "I want the people of Tunisia to understand firstly and lastly that we are in a war with terror, and these savage minority groups will not frighten us," said newly elected President Beji Caid Essebsi in an evening address to the nation.

entry.title: Timeline of unrest in Tunisia since the popular revolt
entry.summary:
October 27-28: Violence erupts in Sidi Bouzid after results of Tunisia's first free election are announced, in which the Islamist Ennahda party wins most seats in a constituent assembly.

December 21: Essebsi wins Tunisia's first free presidential election.

entry.title: 'Our hearts are black': Tunisians in shock after gunmen target tourists in capital
entry.summary: The US secretary of state, John Kerry, said Washington condemned the attack and continued "to support the Tunisian government's efforts to advance a secure, prosperous, and democratic Tunisia".

entry.title: The Latest: Expert: IS applauds Tunisia attack on Twitter
entry.summary: Poland's prime minister has revealed that some of the Polish victims of Tunisia's museum attack were on a tour bus in front of the building when the gunmen opened fire.

entry.title: The Latest: Expert: IS applauds Tunisia attack on Twitter
entry.summary:
The U.N. Security Council has condemned the Bardo museum attack saying that no terrorist action can reverse the path of Tunisia toward democracy.

In a statement issued late Wednesday, the council extended its condolences to the families of the victims, the government of Tunisia and the governments who have lost citizens in the attack.

The office of French President Francois Hollande has issued a statement mourning the victims of attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum.

"We extend our deepest sympathies to the victims of today's heinous violence in Tunisia and condemn in the strongest terms this terrorist attack, which took the lives of innocent Tunisians as well as visiting tourists," Earnest said.

Spanish eyewitness Josep Lluis Cusido says he was inside the Bardo museum in Tunisia when the attack started that left at least 22 people dead and hid behind a pillar to save his life.

entry.title: Tunisia tourist attack - LIVE REPORT
entry.summary: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for today's attack but Tunisia -- the birthplace of the Arab Spring revolutionary movement -- has struggled to tackle a rise in attacks from Islamist extremists.

entry.title: The Latest: 21 killed in Tunisia attack; 2-3 gunmen at large
entry.summary: The United States, the United Nations, France and the UAE are among the nations condemning the attack on a top museum in Tunisia that left 22 people dead, including 17 tourists and 2 gunmen.

entry.title: Tunisia Update: 21 Dead, Gunmen at Large
entry.summary: Tunisia's Interior Ministry says two gunmen and a security officer have been killed in a raid on a major museum that left several tourists dead.

entry.title: Tunisia terrorist attack: Tunisian forces free all hostages from national museum in Tunis after attack leaves 11 dead
entry.summary:
Tunis: Gunmen in military uniforms have stormed Tunisia's national museum, killing 19 people, including an Australian, on Wednesday in one of the worst militant attacks in the country.

Wednesday's assault was the worst attack involving foreigners in Tunisia since an al-Qaeda suicide bombing on a synagogue killed 21 people on the tourist island of Djerba in 2002.

entry.title: Tunisia forces storm museum after terror attack kills 8
entry.summary:
Tourists and visitors line up before being evacuated from the Bardo museum Wednesday, March 18, 2015 in Tunis, after gunmen opened fire at the leading museum in Tunisia's capital.

Gunmen opened fire at a leading museum in Tunisia's capital, killing 19 people including 17 tourists, the Tunisian Prime Minister said.

entry.title: Tunisia terrorist attack: Militants take tourists hostage inside museum at parliament in Tunis
entry.summary: Several Islamist militant groups have emerged in Tunisia since the uprising and authorities estimate about 3000 Tunisians have also joined fighters in Iraq and Syria - raising fears they could return and mount attacks at home.

entry.title: The Latest: Expert: IS applauds Tunisia attack on Twitter
entry.summary: The museum is a leading tourist attraction that chronicles Tunisia's history and houses one of the world's largest collections of Roman mosaics.

entry.title: Tunisia museum tourists gunned down
entry.summary: Tunisia has been struggling to keep extremist violence at bay since the overthrow of its dictator in 2011, and the attack was the worst on a tourist site since an al Qaida car bomb killed 21 people - mostly Germans - in 2002.

entry.title: Shooting Attack On Tunisia Museum Leaves Several Tourists Dead
entry.summary: The assault at the Bardo, Tunisia's largest museum that is housed in a 15th century palace, began sometime after noon local time as scores of European tourists were visiting.

entry.title: At least 8 tourists killed, others hostage in Tunisia parliament attack: official
At least 19 dead in gunman attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum
entry.summary: French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said that the attack on Tunisia was not by chance but because the country represents hope in the Arab world.

entry.title: Tourists killed, others taken hostage in attack on Tunisian parliament, official says
entry.summary:
The Bardo, built in a 15th century palace, is the largest museum in Tunisia and houses one of the world's largest collections of Roman mosaics among its 8,000 works.

Overall, though, violence in Tunisia in recent years has been largely focused on security forces, not foreigners or tourist sites.

The attack came the day after Tunisian security officials confirmed the death in neighbouring Libya of Ahmed Rouissi, leading suspect in Tunisian terror attacks and in the killings of two opposition figures in Tunisia.

entry.title: At least 8 tourists killed, others hostage in Tunisia parliament attack
entry.summary: Tunisia has struggled with violence by Islamic extremists in recent years, including some linked to the Islamic State group.

entry.title: Shots fired near Tunisia's parliament
Tunisia says its security forces surround 2 militants inside museum at parliament
Tunisia to reopen airspace for Libyan flights to Tripoli
entry.summary:
"The first trip will be next Friday from Maitiga to Sfax airport in Tunisia."

Tunisia decided to reopen its consulate in Tripoli last month.

Tunisia is worried violence will spill over from Libya, where Islamic State militants have expanded their influence, exploiting turmoil as the rival governments fight for control.

entry.title: Tunisia dismantles jihadi recruiting cell for Libya
entry.summary:
Rouissi was a top member of Tunisia's Ansar al-Sharia extremist group branded as terrorists by Washington.

Tunisians make up one of the largest contingents of foreign fighters in Syria and Iraq, but more recently militants have been sending jihadis to take part in the conflict in Tunisia's North African neighbor Libya.

Tunisia also said on Tuesday it had dismantled a recruiting cell sending jihadis to fight in Libya and arrested dozens in part of tighter security and border controls to counter Islamist militants.

entry.title: 200 Egyptians flee Libya through Tunisia
Al-Qaeda-linked militants kill four police officers in Tunisia
entry.summary:
It was the first deadly assault this year on government forces in Tunisia, where the police and the army have been hunting down jihadists blamed for a string of attacks on security forces.

Tunisia has seen a rise in Islamist extremism since the 2011 revolution that ousted veteran strongman Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.

entry.title: Government: Radical militants kill 4 Tunisian National Guard
entry.summary:
The attack took place near Mount Chaambi, a national park on the Algerian border that has provided refuge to al-Qaida linked Islamist radicals blamed for attacks against army and politicians in Tunisia for the past two years.

Despite the efforts of Tunisia's small army, attacks have continued around Mount Chaambi.
